Groundnut is cultivated in 2.0 lakh hectares across Telangana region making it one of the major crops of the state. It is widely grown in Mahbubnagar, Warangal, Nalgonda and Karimnagar Districts. Crop rotation is very important in Groundnut farming, this helps to utilize nutrients efficiently utilization and to reduces soil borne diseases.

Sugarcane
Kamareddy region of Telangana is known for its sugarcane production and around 70 per cent of the farmers cultivate this crop. Sugarcane is grown in Kamareddy, Sadashiva Nagur, Machareddy and Domakonda areas.The sugarcane plantation is one of the major crops of this district. In view of this Sugar factories like Indira Sugars and Gayathri Sugar factories are established. They play an important role in the economy of the district of Kamareddy District.Sugarcane plays an important role in the economy of the district. The sugarcane crushing season will begin at Magi in Kamareddy district and about a Many villages in Kamareddy and Surrounding Districts will supply cane to the factories.

Uttar Pradesh

Uttar Pradesh, located in northern India, is one of the leading agricultural states in the country. The state's diverse agro-climatic conditions and fertile soil support the cultivation of various crops. Some of the major crops grown in Uttar Pradesh include Wheat, Rice, Sugarcane, Maize, and Potato.

Wheat
Wheat is a major cereal crop in Uttar Pradesh. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions for wheat farming. Uttar Pradesh is one of the leading producers of wheat in India. Wheat cultivation provides food security and is an important source of income for farmers in the state.

Rice
Rice cultivation is significant in Uttar Pradesh. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions, including fertile soil and adequate water resources, for rice farming. Uttar Pradesh produces a significant quantity of rice, contributing to the state's food security and local consumption.

Sugarcane
Sugarcane cultivation is prominent in Uttar Pradesh. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions for sugarcane farming. Uttar Pradesh is one of the leading producers of sugarcane in India. Sugarcane is primarily grown for sugar production and also used for jaggery and molasses. Sugarcane farming provides income and employment opportunities to farmers and supports the state's sugar industry.

Maize
Maize cultivation is notable in Uttar Pradesh. The state has favorable agro-climatic conditions for maize production. Maize is grown for both human consumption and animal feed. Uttar Pradesh produces a significant quantity of maize, contributing to the state's agricultural economy and livestock industry.

Potato
Potato cultivation is prominent in Uttar Pradesh. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions for potato farming. Uttar Pradesh is one of the leading producers of potatoes in India. Potatoes are widely used in culinary preparations and have high demand in the domestic and international markets. Potato farming provides income and employment opportunities to farmers and supports the state's economy.

Uttarakhand

Uttarakhand, located in the northern part of India, has a diverse agricultural landscape and cultivates a variety of crops. The state's agro-climatic conditions and fertile soil contribute to the cultivation of various crops. Some of the major crops grown in Uttarakhand include Rice, Wheat, Maize, Soybean, and Potato.

Rice
Rice is a staple food crop in Uttarakhand. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions, including fertile soil and adequate water resources, for rice cultivation. Uttarakhand produces a significant quantity of rice, contributing to the state's food security and local consumption. Rice farming provides income and livelihoods to farmers and plays a crucial role in the state's economy.

Wheat
Wheat is a major cereal crop in Uttarakhand. The state has favorable agro-climatic conditions for wheat farming. Wheat cultivation provides food security and is an important source of income for farmers in Uttarakhand. The state contributes significantly to the wheat production of the country.

Maize
Maize cultivation is significant in Uttarakhand. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions for maize production. Maize is grown for both human consumption and animal feed. Uttarakhand produces a significant quantity of maize, contributing to the state's agricultural economy and livestock industry. Maize farming provides income diversification for farmers and serves as an important crop for the local economy.

Soybean
Soybean cultivation is notable in Uttarakhand. The state has favorable agro-climatic conditions for soybean farming. Soybean is an important oilseed crop and is used for oil extraction, animal feed, and various food products. Soybean farming provides income and employment opportunities to farmers and contributes to the state's agricultural economy.

Potato
Potato cultivation is prominent in Uttarakhand. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions for potato farming. Potatoes are widely used in culinary preparations and have high demand in the domestic market. Potato farming provides income and employment opportunities to farmers and supports the state's economy.

West Bengal

West Bengal, located in eastern India, has a diverse agricultural landscape and cultivates a variety of crops. The state's agro-climatic conditions and fertile soil contribute to the cultivation of various crops. Some of the major crops grown in West Bengal include Rice, Jute, Tea, Potato, Sugarcane, Maize, Wheat, Pulses (such as Moong Dal and Arhar Dal), Oilseeds (such as Mustard and Sesame), and Vegetables (such as Brinjal, Tomato, and Cauliflower).

Rice
Rice is the staple food crop of West Bengal. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions, including fertile soil and adequate water resources, for rice cultivation. West Bengal is one of the leading producers of rice in India. Rice farming provides food security and is an important source of income for farmers in the state.

Jute
Jute cultivation is prominent in West Bengal. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions for jute farming. West Bengal is known for its high-quality jute production, contributing significantly to the jute industry. Jute farming provides income and employment opportunities to farmers and supports the state's economy.

Tea
Tea cultivation is significant in West Bengal, particularly in the Darjeeling and Dooars regions. The cool and hilly terrain of these regions creates favorable conditions for tea farming. West Bengal's tea estates produce high-quality tea leaves that are used in the tea industry. Tea cultivation provides income and employment opportunities to farmers and supports the state's economy.

Potato
Potato cultivation is prominent in West Bengal. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions for potato farming. West Bengal is one of the leading producers of potatoes in India. Potatoes are widely used in culinary preparations and have high demand in the domestic market. Potato farming provides income and employment opportunities to farmers and supports the state's economy.

Sugarcane
Sugarcane cultivation is notable in West Bengal. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions for sugarcane farming. Sugarcane is primarily grown for sugar production and also used for jaggery and molasses. West Bengal's sugarcane farming contributes to the state's sugar industry. It provides income and employment opportunities to farmers and supports the economy.

Maize
Maize cultivation is significant in West Bengal. The state has favorable agro-climatic conditions for maize production. Maize is grown for both human consumption and animal feed. West Bengal produces a significant quantity of maize, contributing to the state's agricultural economy and livestock industry.

Wheat
Wheat cultivation is notable in West Bengal. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions for wheat farming. Wheat is an important cereal crop and provides food security in the state. Wheat cultivation provides income and livelihoods to farmers and contributes to the state's agricultural economy.

Pulses (Moong Dal and Arhar Dal)
Pulses are essential crops in West Bengal, contributing to the state's protein production and nutrition. Farmers in West Bengal cultivate various pulses, including Moong Dal (Green Gram) and Arhar Dal (Pigeon Pea). Pulses are rich in protein and essential nutrients. Pulse cultivation helps in improving soil fertility through nitrogen fixation and provides income to farmers. It contributes to food security, nutritional well-being, and the rural economy in West Bengal.

Oilseeds (Mustard and Sesame)
Oilseed crops, such as Mustard and Sesame, are grown in West Bengal. The state has suitable agro-climatic conditions for oilseed farming. Mustard seeds are used in cooking, oil extraction, and as a spice. Sesame seeds are also used for oil extraction and as an ingredient in various food preparations. Oilseed cultivation provides income and employment opportunities to farmers and plays an important role in the state's economy.

Vegetables (Brinjal, Tomato, Cauliflower, etc.)
West Bengal cultivates a variety of vegetables that include Brinjal, Tomato, Cauliflower, and many others. The state's farmers produce a wide range of vegetables to meet the local demand and supply markets. Vegetable cultivation provides income, nutrition, and food security to farmers and contributes to local markets and consumption.
